content: Given the following mathematical function expressions, you need to calculate the indefinite integral of the function (excluding the constant C), then substitute 'x=4' into the result of the indefinite integral, and finally provide me with the integer result of the expression by rounding down. (The answer should consist of only a single integer number representing the final result, with no additional words.)

The indefinite integral of (1+x)/ln(x) is:

∫(1+x)/ln(x) dx = ∫x/ln(x) dx + ∫1 dx

= (x/ln(x))' + C

= 1 + C

Now, if you substitute 'x=4' into the indefinite integral, you get:

∫(4/ln(4)) dx = 1 + C

= 1 + C = ∫(1+x)/ln(x) dx for x=4

The result is 5. Note that I have rounded down the final result to an integer.

The indefinite integral of (1+x)/ln(x) + x is:

∫(1+x)/ln(x) dx + ∫x dx

= ∫(x+1)/ln(x) dx + x²

= (x²/ln(x))' + x² + C

= x² + x²/ln(x) + C

Now, if you substitute 'x=4' into the indefinite integral, you get:

∫(4+1)/ln(4) + 4² dx = x² + x²/ln(x) + C

= 4² + 4²/ln(4) + C = 25

The result is 25. Note that I have rounded down the final result to an integer.
